p: Venezuelan equine encephalitis (VEE) is a mosquito-borne illness, endemic in areas of South America, Central America, Mexico, Florida and Trinidad, that primarily affects equids and humans [ 1, 2, 3]. VEE disease in humans is typically manifested as an acute self-limiting febrile illness of 3 to 5 days duration, with an abrupt onset of fever and chills, severe headache, malaise, myalgia, and nausea. Unlike equids, encephalitis and mortality in humans from VEEV infection is uncommon (< 1% of cases) and is observed mainly in children and the elderly [ 4, 5, 6].
